awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Redshirt in Engineering Consortium
awd_abstract_narration:
Low-income students are underrepresented in engineering and more likely to struggle in engineering programs.  Research has found that increasing first and second-year retention enhances the ability of academically talented low-income students to successfully graduate with engineering degrees. In this collaborative research project six institutions will replicate, improve, and test a model of student success originally developed at the University of Colorado, Boulder. The model is designed to increase the retention, success, and graduation of low-income (Pell-eligible) academically talented students from underserved populations. The project will make scholarship awards to 800 students across a consortium of the six partner institutions. To support the students, the project will adapt and implement an ecosystem of high quality evidence-based curricular and co-curricular activities. Members of the consortium are: the University of Colorado, Boulder; the University of Washington; Washington State University; Boise State University; the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign; and the University of California, San Diego.  

The Redshirt in Engineering Consortium is committed to propagating the "Redshirt" model, which focuses primarily on the first-year of college and consists of intrusive academic advising, an innovative first-year academic curriculum, community building, and career awareness. The term "redshirt" refers to the idea of providing an extra year of preparation for the rigors of engineering curricula. A quantitative and qualitative mixed methods research study will examine the implementation of the model under different conditions and with different student populations.  A comparative longitudinal study will examine differences in expected student outcomes between scholarship recipients and similar students who are pursuing engineering degrees.  The primary analytic approach for the ethnographic research will be the Constant Comparative Analysis, which will involve concurrent engagement in data collection and data analysis.

por.por_cntn:
The Academic Community for Engineering Success (ACES) Scholars program began at the University of California, San Diego in 2016 to support low-income engineering students and increase their retention in engineering majors. ACES is part of the Redshirt in Engineering Consortium which is funded by a collaborative NSF S-STEM grant and includes six universities: University of Colorado, Boulder, University of Washington, Seattle, Washington State University, Boise State University, and University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign. Over the past six years these universities have used the Redshirt model as a guide to implement programming and share best practices for supporting low-income engineering students.  Each university faced unique challenges and brought different skill sets and resources, and based on these varying experiences the Redshirt model evolved to focus on four key pillars:

  • Intrusive advising
  • Mastery of STEM basics
  • Professional and personal skills development
  • Community building

At UC San Diego, ACES Scholars began the program by participating in the Summer Engineering Institute (SEI) the summer before their first year. SEI is a 5-week program open to all engineering students, and ACES Scholars were awarded scholarships allowing them to attend at no cost. As part of SEI, ACES Scholars lived together on campus, took 6 credits of engineering courses, participated in social and community building activities, became familiar with campus resources, and attended professional development workshops. During COVID, SEI was modified to a non-credit bearing, 5-day virtual experience. Throughout the academic year, ACES Scholars received small scholarships, participated in ACES discussions and workshops that encouraged engagement with student organizations, internships, and undergraduate research, and built both study and professional development skills. First-year ACES Scholars were also matched with engineering faculty mentors as well as with older ACES students who served as peer mentors. Faculty mentors provided guidance and answered questions, and several ACES Scholars went on to engage in undergraduate research in their faculty mentors? labs. ACES Scholars also built a peer network, engaging with each other and attending ACES socials.

Ninety-seven students participated in the ACES Scholars program over the six years of the S-STEM award. Fifty percent of the ACES Scholars were women, 44% were underrepresented minorities, 63% were first generation college students, and 92% were Pell-eligible. To date, 79% of students who began as ACES Scholars persist in engineering or have earned their engineering degree. Of the 21% who switched to non-engineering majors, 70% were retained in STEM. The average 4-year graduation rate for the first two cohorts of ACES Scholars is 66%, and the average 4-year graduation rate for the first two cohorts of ACES Scholars who were retained in engineering is 79%. This compares favorably with the average UC San Diego 4-year graduation rates of 66% for all engineering students and 56% for Pell-eligible engineering students.

ACES and the Redshirt model significantly impacted students? experiences and perceptions. The Center for Evaluation & Research for STEM Equity (CERSE) surveyed students across all six Redshirt universities and found that, compared with non-Redshirt students, Redshirt students felt a greater sense of belonging in engineering, were more familiar with campus resources, and were more comfortable connecting with instructors for help.  Redshirt participation was also associated with increasing perception of STEM abilities and it buffered students from the decline in self-confidence experienced by non-Redshirt students over the first two years in college. Redshirt students had a greater understanding of engineering career pathways, and Redshirt participation was associated with a statistically significant increase in career understanding. This association was particularly strong for ACES Scholars who also had statistically significant increases in the perception of their leadership abilities, resume writing, and interviewing skills.

Additionally, a UC San Diego survey of ACES Scholars and a comparison group of non-ACES engineering students found that, among survey respondents, ACES Scholars are more likely than non-ACES students to engage with the engineering community and specifically to:

  • Be involved in professional or student groups for women or minority engineers, such as the Society of Women Engineers, National Society of Black Engineers, or the Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers (61% ACES, 24% non-ACES)
  • Participate in IDEA Engineering Student Center sponsored activities (74% ACES, 35% non-ACES)
  • Engage in undergraduate research (70% ACES; 31% non-ACES). Note that the difference between groups is even more pronounced when looking at specific populations. For example, among Latinx students, 80% of ACES survey respondents were involved in undergraduate research compared to only 13% of non-ACES students.

When asked to name the top three elements of the ACES program that had the greatest impact on their success, ACES Scholars most often listed: the Summer Engineering Institute (88%), having a cohort of peer scholars (60%), and faculty mentoring (32%). 


 

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2022
Modified by: Pamela C Cosman
